node.title: 'Depressed, lethargic': UK pets testing positive for COVID-19
node.description: Some have difficulty breathing because of the accumulation of fluid in their lungs.
node.content: ["Vets in the UK have noticed an increase in pets coming in for treatment with symptoms of COVID-19.", "\"These were dogs and cats that were depressed, lethargic, they lost appetite,\" said Dr Luca Ferasin, a veterinary cardiologist at The Ralph Veterinary Referral Centre in Buckinghamshire says.", "\"And they had either difficulty breathing because of accumulation of fluid in their lungs due to the heart disease, or they were fainting because of an underlying abnormal heart rhythm.\"", "Only about 1.5 percent of pets referred to Dr Ferasin before December last year were diagnosed with myocarditis - but this saw a dramatic rise between December and March to 12.5 percent with myocarditis.", "But most interestingly, the vet found many of the pets' owners had either tested positive for COVID-19 or had symptoms of the disease within three to six weeks of their pets becoming ill.\u00a0", "Dr Ferasin tested 11 animals for COVID-19 for the journal Veterinary Record.", "The results showed that two cats and one dog tested positive for the alpha variant of the virus, and two additional cats and an additional dog tested positive for COVID antibodies.\u00a0", "The remaining five animals tested negative for antibodies and the virus.", "All of the pets in this study recovered after supportive treatment with supplemental oxygen and diuretics to help remove fluid from the lungs with the exception of one cat with persistent abnormal heart rhythm, which the owners decided to euthanize."]
